title: Biconditional elimination
summary: Biconditional elimination is the name of two valid rules of inference of propositional logic. It allows for one to infer a conditional from a biconditional. If P ↔ Q {\displaystyle P\leftrightarrow Q} is true, then one may infer that P → Q {\displaystyle P\to Q} is true, and also that Q → P {\displaystyle Q\to P} is true.[1] For example, if it's true that I'm breathing if and only if I'm alive, then it's true that if I'm breathing, I'm alive; likewise, it's true that if I'm alive, I'm breathing.
